learning_outcomes.description: Command and utilise core theoretical macroeconomic models to explain real world observations, problems and puzzles. This command will show sensitivity for how macroeconomic conditions vary across countries and / or over time.
Identify key contemporary macroeconomic problems, both domestic and international, and discuss possible solutions and potential innovations towards improving current policies and practices.
Explain the connections between short run, long run, and very long forces on the economy, and the appropriate policy responses to each of them.
Develop your confidence and abilities to use mathematics and logic to make reasoned arguments about economic issues.

assessments.task_description:
30 minute quiz conducted during the regular lecture time.

There are 4 lecture quizzes worth 10% each. Students may choose any 3 of these tests for a total of 30% assessment. If all 4 tests are taken, the student will be given their best 3 marks.

The quizzes will be conducted in Lectures 5, 7, 9 and 11. The topic will be the content in the prior week's lecture. E.g. The quiz in Lecture 5 will be on Lecture 4 content.

No deferred quizzes will be offered.

Note on use of AI in this assessment: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission occurs at the end of the 30 minutes scheduled for the quiz .
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
27/04/2026 - 11/05/2026

The assignment will be available from 27 April at 9am.

Submission is due by 11 May at 4pm.
assessments.task_description:
This assignment will consist of a set of questions requiring analysis of the Reserve Bank of Australia Statement on Monetary Policy, February 2026.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission is via the link in Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final exam will consist of short-answer questions requiring analysis and discussion.

The final exam is designed to cover all learning objectives and to test both depth and breadth of students' knowledge of material covered throughout the course.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
